article:
A 'widow' is a woman whose spouse has
died, while a 'widower' is a man whose spouse has died. The
state of having lost one's spouse to death is termed widowhood. This term can be
used for either sex, at least according to some dictionaries, [http://www.c-
ollinsdictionary.com/dictionary/english/widowhood "Widowhood" as defined by Col-
lins] [http://oxforddictionaries.com/definition/english/widowhood?vie-
w=uk "Widowhood" as defined by Oxford] but the word widowerhood is also
listed in some dictionaries. [http://www.collinsdictionary.com/dictionary/e-
nglish/widowerhood "Widowerhood" as defined by Collins] [http://www.merriam-
webster.com/dictionary/widowerhood "Widowerhood" as defined by Merriam-
Webster's] Occasionally, the word viduity is used. The adjective form for
either sex [http://www.collinsdictionary.com/dictionary/english/widowed
"Widowed" as defined by
Collins] [http://dictionary.cambridge.org/dictionary/british/widowed
"Widowed" as defined by Cambridge] is widowed. The treatment of widows
around the world varies, but unequal benefits and treatment generally received
by widows versus widowers globally has spurred an interest in the issue by human
rights activists. Owen, Margaret. A World of Widows.
Illustrated. Atlantic Highlands, NJ: Zed Books, 1996. 181-183. eBook.
